source.description:
Cell plating conditions will vary depending on your experiment and cell type. Usually 2,000-10,000 cells per well.
For best compatibility with ICCB-L robotics please use GREINER MICROPLATE, 384 WELL, PS, F-BOTTOM, µCLEAR now sold as Perkin Elmer CellCarrier ULTRA

source.body:
This protocol has only been tested with adherent mammalian cells.
Note that you should ONLY plate cells in wells you want data from. Any unused wells need to be empty of cells. PBS or Media is fine, but no cells.
If you are setting this up on your own robotic system you can use a different plate. Just be consistent with the plates used for proper robotic head height.

source.description:
Purified RNA or intact adherent cells in 384 well format can be used for 3'-DGE. 
(Note, we have had better experience with starting from intact cells.)
1. If starting with purified RNA, skip to Step 22.
2. If starting with intact cells, proceed to Step 3.
3. Lysate from 4 x 96 well plates can also be used. 96 well plates are re-arrayed to 384 well format in the first stage of RNA purification.

Prepare enough Lysis Buffer for the number of samples. (Protocol is for 384 well format)
TCL buffer + 1 % ?-mercaptoethanol
ABC
1ReagentWellPlate
2TCL Buffer9.9 µL4.22 mL
3ß-mercaptoethanol0.1 µL42.2 µl
4Total10 µL4.22 mL

ABC
1ReagentWellPlate
2TCL Buffer9.9 µL4.22 mL
3ß-mercaptoethanol0.1 µL42.2 µl
4Total10 µL4.22 mL

Aspirate media and wash wells once with PBS.
We do this with a Biotek plate washer:
Remove most of the PBS. Our robotic system usually leaves behind about 10 µl of PBS.

Add
of lysis buffer to each well of your 384-well plate.

Incubate for
on belly dancer to aid in lysis. Freeze
until ready to proceed with RNA extraction.

source.body: Incubation can be 0-30 min. Be consistent with your samples.

source.description:
Lysate plate can be stored at
until RNA extraction. Use within a few weeks of lysis is best, but we have stored samples for months with successful extraction.

We use a 384 well multichannel (16 channel) pipette to make this easier.

*Important - seal water plate and spin down 1000 xg.
Removes any bubbles that form under the water in the plate.
If purifying multiple plates, can double the volume of water. Other plates need to be fresh for each reaction.

Remove the reaction plate from the magnet and resuspend the beads.

Look at plate after mixing and be sure it looks well mixed.

source.body:
If mixing is problematic you can take plate off the Bravo, seal it, smack it down then vortex it. Then quick spin followed by another mix step on the Bravo.
If the SPRI beads look clumpy/sandy when mixing it is possible the extraction failed due to an issue with the lysis buffer, beads or ethanol. Heating the plate up to 50°C can help with the elution. This should be a last resort option.
If samples this hard to dissolve / look clumpy it may be worth aborting the experiment unless samples are precious

source.title: BRAVO DGE program for RNA purification (step 1 of DGE program)

source.description:
Pick random wells to check RNA concentration by Qubit.
  • 2-5 ng/µl is the goal
  • Use 2µl of sample to check concentration
  • If starting from 96 well plates concentrations are often much higher 5-10 ng/µl

source.body:
Can also take some sample to run RNA pico BioAnalyzer to check RNA quality.
This is usually done in the pilot 3'-DGE run. On the actual sample plate BioA is not usually run.

before moving on to RT/Library prep.

source.body:

Seal and spin RNA plate before using for RT step.

source.body: If using RNA as input, make sure to normalize concentrations (minimum: 0.5 ng/µl, optimum 20 ng/µl) across samples.

Using the BRAVO Add
of the master mix to each well of the "PCR plate".
Change tips after every 4 dispense steps.

source.body: There is JUST barely enough master mix for a whole plate. In the last dispense watch to make sure enough master mix went into all wells. It is sometimes necessary to dispense into a few wells by hand.

source.description:
Using the BRAVO, transfer
(assume ~5 ng/µl) of the RNA from the RNA plate to the PCR Plate.
(Be sure the RNA plate is taped down to the magnet.)
Mix
3x

source.body: It is important the RNA plate is on the magnet for 1-2 minutes before transferring. There are often residual SPRI beads in the RNA plate that you do not want carried over into the PCR plate for the RT reaction.

source.description:
Seal the plate and bring to
incubator. This could be done in qPCR machine. We use an air incubator with a metal block pre-equilibrated in the incubator for even heating.

source.body: Block: Labnet D12384 Aluminum Dry Bath Dual Block, Holds 384 Well PCR Plate

source.description:

at

Fit 384 well plate upside down onto collection plate (VBlok reservoir from Clickbio VBLOK200).

Spin 1,000 xg for
.
Collect cDNA into 50 mL Falcon tube. Expected volume ~3.2-3.6 mL.

Add 5x volume Qiagen PB buffer (3.4 mL = 17 mL, 3.6 mL = 18 mL)
Add
directly to a 50 mL Falcon tube.
Use the rest to rinse out collection plate then pipette into the 50 mL Falcon tube with the rest of the sample.

Load the sample onto QIAquick PCR purification column using vacuum filter system.
The loading will slow down as more sample is loaded.

source.body: Jam the luer-lock end of a 3 or 5 mL syringe barrel onto the column to make a "tube extender" to allow for easier loading of the column.

source.description:
Once all the sample has been loaded, wash the syringe barrel column with
of PE buffer.

Remove the syringe barrel column and wash the column once more with
of PE buffer.

Dry the column by centrifuging at >10,000 xg for
.

of nuclease free water (usually with water warmed to ~
.
Let water sit on column for
, then spin at >10,000 xg for
.

Check concentration of sample using dsDNA HS Qubit Assay.
Expected yield 30-80 ng/µl.

Proceed through Exo I treatment and amplification before pausing protocol.

source.description:
Can leave reaction at
overnight.

Dilute PCR mix with
Water for 100 µl total reaction volume.

Mix sample with
Ampure XP beads at a ratio of 1:0.7
Be sure Ampure beads are at Room Temperature and fully resuspended before use.

source.body: Ampure XP is used instead of homebrew SPRI beads in order to ensure best size selection at this critical stage where we are removing any primer dimers.

source.description:
Incubate for
at
.
Place the tube on the magnet stand until clear and discard supernatant.

Wash with
of 80% EtOH while the tube is on the magnet. Discard the supernatant.

Repeat wash step once more.
Use aspirator to remove residual ethanol to speed up drying time.

Air dry beads for
.

source.body: Depending on temperature and humidity, the beads may dry faster. Therefore it is important to regularly check the beads to avoid over-drying.

source.description:
Take sample off the magnet and elute cDNA in
H2O.

Can leave sample at
until ready to continue.

Quantify the cDNA using the Quant-iT PicoGreen dsDNA assay kit or dsDNA HS Qubit following the manufacturer's protocol. Note will QC again with Qubit after diluting sample for Nextera XT protocol.
Use
of clean cDNA for quantification.
Usually ~15-60 ng/µl

Optional: Quality check the cDNA using the Agilent 2100 Bioanalyzer with High Sensitivity DNA Analysis Kits.
(Usually do not bother with this step, but can be informative when you are new to the protocol.)

Prepare 20ul of a 1 ng/µL solution of cDNA for Nextera XT Tagmentation.
Use 5ul to check concentration by Qubit.
Further dilute sample to 0.8ng/ul for Nextera XT protocol.

source.body: Can also use Nextera FLEX kit instead of XT kit. Use mid range amount of sample input ~250ng and use 1/2 volume reactions. Follow manual instructions performing x5 cycles of amplification. For the final purification, follow the protocol which includes a double sided SPRI selection (0.5x followed by additional 1x).

source.body: If doing a gel cleanup use a 1:1.2 ratio to capture as much cDNA since the primers will be cut out from the gel.

Incubate for

.
Place the tube on the magnet stand until clear and discard supernatant.

Wash with

air incubator then finish drying at RT. You can dry at RT only, but will take much longer to dry.

source.body: Depending on temperature and humidity, the beads may dry faster. Therefore it is important to regularly check the beads and avoid over-drying.

source.description:
Remove tube from the magnet and elute library in
H2O.

Quantify sample using Qubit dsDNA HS. Expected yield is low 1-4 ng/µl (which is ~4 nM).
If yields are much higher could cycle for fewer cycles during final amplification.
Run sample on Tapestation or Bioanalyzer to assess size. Below is an example from the tapestation.

Store sample at
until sequenced.

We have found that running a single 384 well DGE plate at a time is best for clustering on a NextSeq. For a NovaSeq run, multiple plates can be pooled together.
These libraries are difficult to cluster appropriately: usually you need to load almost 2x the concentration you would normally run to get good clustering. (Test this in your own hands!)

Libraries are run in a paired-end manner:
17 cycles Read 1 Well index and UMI
8 cycles Index 1 Nextera Plate Index
60 (or more) cycles Read 2 cDNA Fragment

BCL file to FASTQ file conversion is a bit tricky due to the short length of Read 1. Speak to your sequencing core to ensure you get your data correctly.
The code below has worked for our team:
bcl2fastq --adapter-stringency 0.9 --barcode-mismatches 0 --fastq-compression-level 4 --ignore-missing-bcls --ignore-missing-filter --ignore-missing-positions --min-log-level INFO --minimum-trimmed-read-length 0 --sample-sheet /n/boslfs/INSTRUMENTS/illumina/190107_NB501677_0376_AHTLM5BGX7/SampleSheet.csv --runfolder-dir /n/boslfs/INSTRUMENTS/illumina/190107_NB501677_0376_AHTLM5BGX7 --output-dir /n/boslfs/ANALYSIS/190107_NB501677_0376_AHTLM5BGX7 --processing-threads 8 --no-lane-splitting --mask-short-adapter-reads 0 --use-bases-mask y17,i8,y46

at RT to elute the cDNA

Then place the sample back on the magnet and remove
. Use residual sample on beads to quantitate sample with Qubit.

materials.name: Deoxynucleotide Solution Mix - 40 umol of each
Maxima H Minus Reverse Transcriptase (200 U/uL)
Nextera XT DNA Sample Preparation Kit, 96 samples
Marsh Plates 384 Well Polypropylene Storage Plates

description:
This protocol is for the high-throughput transcriptome screening method called, 3’ Digital Gene Expression (3’-DGE). In this method RNA is purified from cell lysate and cDNA is generated by oligo dT priming, during which unique molecular identifiers (UMIs) are incorporated and strand-specificity is preserved. The 3’-DGE protocol has been optimized for 384 well plate experiments with a few thousand cells per well. The 3’-DGE method and a similar method known as DRUG-seq have been shown to be able to recapitulate 85% of the transcriptome you can obtain with standard mRNA-seq. In our experience using 3’-DGE we sequence each well at a low depth, aiming for ~1 million reads per sample which allows us to asses 40-80% of the transcriptome depending on the cell type. It is possible to sequence these samples to a greater depth if warranted. It is important to keep in mind that in 3’-DGE, and most low-input methods, only the 3’ poly-A end of the transcript is preserved. Therefore, this technique cannot be used if it is important to capture splice-isoforms or transcripts that do not have a poly-A tail.
This is a modification of the SCRB-seq protocol originally published here:
https://www.biorxiv.org/content/10.1101/003236v1;
Recognition also goes to the Enard group and their modifications to SCRB-seq found here:
https://www.protocols.io/view/mcscrb-seq-protocol-p9kdr4w
The home-brew SPRI beads used in this study are made with this protocol:
dx.doi.org/10.17504/protocols.io.bkppkvmn
